subject: Re: [junit] How to automate the testcases!
msgSnippet: ... format...) ... and ... Standard universal data processing answer: It depends. ... His locale, usually. If locale-sensitivity is required, then
messageBody:
On 2002-08-22 at 15:20 Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>>> - wrong type of String (numeric instead of text, wrong date
format...)
>
>> Boo! The problem is that the code is not OO. Where are the number
and
>> date objects that create themselves from string representations?
>
>How do you handle "5/10/2002" entered on a webpage?

Standard universal data processing answer: "It depends."

> Is it May (US) or
>November
>(Europe)? What is the most important from the user point of view: the
>locale
>of the server or his locale?

His locale, usually. If locale-sensitivity is required, then
DateFactory.makeDate(dateAsString, locale) should do the trick.

>Same thing with numbers: "1,000.10" (US) equals "1'000,10" or
"1.000,10"
>(Europe).

I hope that NumberFactory.makeNumber(numberAsString, locale) will do
here, as well.

>Or course your program should handle this gracefully but with a user
freely
>entering information, you'll have surprises.

The best you can do is ask the user to do the right thing and politely
remind him that he did the wrong thing when he does the wrong thing. :)

>> Not with reflection... as long as you always handle the "null"
>> argument the same way.
>
>we all wait for your automatic reflection tester TestCase :-) "As
long as
>you
>always handle the 'null' argument the same way" is a REALLY strong
>hypothesis.

Agreed, but in my experience it's generally true. I have worked with
defensive programmers in the past who throw a NullPointerException for
null arguments. It would be best to add a "not null" modifier to the
formal parameter list, but I am not in a position to modify the Java
language.

>StringBuffer.append accepts null arguments, String.compareTo doesn't.

Yes, and that's sad.

>Anyway, I prefer to focus on positive testing (without forgetting
negative
>testing, but not spending all my time with this issue). When the
>application
>does what it has to do, it's already a good result :-)

I am leaning in that direction more and more these days, and I quite
like it so far.
